snippet.textDisplay:
I think the point about Cummins's book is that you really have to consider who it's actually for.

Is it for Mexican people, who have been here their whole lives? I don't really see why it would be, but it's possible they might enjoy it in concept. Then they start reading it, and see that it's full of stereotypes.

What about Mexican immigrants who have actually had that experience, documented or otherwise? Obviously not, because it's supposedly grossly inaccurate. It would be like reading a dramatization of the events of your actual life, written by someone who isn't even your race. And then they make a bunch of stereotypes about your race, too.

Is it for people who are "on the wall" about immigration issues? I wouldn't think so, because I doubt anyone who's even slightly opposed to immigration would read a book about it.

Is it for people who strongly oppose immigration? Obviously not. Those people can't read.

So, who is it for?

It's for white people.

Specifically, white people who want to feel better about their situation, like if you're pro dog adoption and you read a story about a sad dog getting adopted. It's like a feel-good story.

...and now it's just got 10,000 times the publicity.

snippet.textDisplay:
The controversy around American Dirt is so insanely baseless in my opinion. At least the part where people criticize the author for not being an immigrant, and from there drawing the conclusion that "It WaSn'T HEr StOrY tO TeLL". Oh, so just because she hasn't experienced what she writes about in the book personally, that suddenly means that she should be barred from writing about it?? It's not like her writing about this subject makes it so no one else can write about it. If you are an immigrant, and want to write about your personal experience GO DO THAT. Tell your story. If your personal experience makes you more qualified at telling this story, then that will manifest itself in your book being more successful than this one, right? But this woman wanted to write about this subject, and in a free country she should be able to do so if she wants to. And if the book is bad you can ridicule it for being inaccurate, or poorly written, or biased, or what ever you feel is wrong. However, if the book is good it's just more power, and attention for the cause. And it's not like her being white will automatically result in the book being bad. Maybe she did her research? Maybe she has a refreshing new look from the outside in? Or maybe, just maybe, the book just happens to be telling an engaging and heartfelt story, the same way good sci fi or fantasy books do without the author having personally experienced these worlds they write about.


I can't say anything about the contents of the book, because I haven't read it. But the claims that the author is in the wrong for writing and publishing the book just based on her heritage, and the color of her skin, is not only baseless, but also racist and dangerous.

snippet.textDisplay: Memoirs of a Geisha, To Kill a Mockingbird, hell, even Schindler's List (and many more I could list if I really wanted to spend time on a YouTube comment)  all are based around things that really happened and weren’t written by people who experienced them. All three (and many more) have stereotyping and artistic liberties. I think it’s just quite short sighted to have this outrage about something many people aren’t going to read/ aren’t well read enough to know there are hundreds of books that match the same description of inaccuracies, even if the authors researched and did their due-diligence.

snippet.textDisplay:
I think that the “Gay Agenda” stems from people believing that being gay is a choice. If it was something that could be chosen like a fetish, then one might view LGBT as an agenda trying to normalize something that may feel wrong to them.

In reality, being gay or bisexual is not a choice and what some view as an addenda to make straight people gay, is actually an attempt to make LGBT people feel accepted.

Wearing feminine clothing like Lil Nas X is a choice, but so is a woman wearing a suit. Clothing helps us express who we are or how we feel.

This is all just my opinion, if you disagree feel free to comment. Thank you!

snippet.textDisplay: I am Latina. But unlike other Latinas, I was born a US citizen because Puerto Rico is a US Commonwealth. I moved to the states when I was 10, and I definitely struggled to learn the language, and even harder, the culture. My parents had an even harder time adjusting, since they were in their mid 30s and left the island for the first time. My mom was and still is victim to racism on a constant basis. Me and my brother look like my dad, who passes as white. But i can never ever understand what my latino brothers and sisters have gone thru immigrating to the US. We had very different journeys getting here. Being latina doesn’t mean their stories belong to me or should be told by me, as i cant even imagine. I’ve had friends growing up, I’ve seen the fear in their eyes, the fear they live with. My friend’s dad was deported when i was in my teens and she’s still traumatized over it. Its been almost 20 years. I don’t know what that feels like. That author should have at the very least had a co-author or consultants or an interview.... just someone that had gone thru this should have been involved. I mean ur including freakin stereotypes in ur book? For real? Ur hurting “ur own people” cuz ur grandma was Puertorican? Really? Smh

snippet.textDisplay: As a Puerto Rican, I liked American Dirt. Admittedly, at birth, Borinquen are American citizens so obviously our experiences will never be the same. I do, however, agree that it's a trojan horse. Is it riddled with bs stereotypes? Absolutely. 100% yes. Cummins could have and should have looked deeper into her own background before writing it. And I can definitely see how it's coming across as appropriation. But I also feel like we need a sugarcoated racially ambiguous book or movie to talk about this stuff because it will get the people who are otherwise undecided to take a closer look or at least research for five minutes so they can come up with their own educated point of view on the subject. Does it suck that we have to whittle our cultures down into happy, white-washed, bite-sized snippets? Fuck yes. But we're not going to change the narrative if we stay on our soap boxes yelling about how people need to educate themselves about us. It's not going to happen. If we want people to be educated, we need to educate them. this is one of the ways we do that.
snippet.textOriginal: As a Puerto Rican, I liked American Dirt. Admittedly, at birth, Borinquen are American citizens so obviously our experiences will never be the same. I do, however, agree that it's a trojan horse. Is it riddled with bs stereotypes? Absolutely. 100% yes. Cummins could have and should have looked deeper into her own background before writing it. And I can definitely see how it's coming across as appropriation. But I also feel like we need a sugarcoated racially ambiguous book or movie to talk about this stuff because it will get the people who are otherwise undecided to take a closer look or at least research for five minutes so they can come up with their own *educated* point of view on the subject. Does it suck that we have to whittle our cultures down into happy, white-washed, bite-sized snippets? Fuck yes. But we're not going to change the narrative if we stay on our soap boxes yelling about how people need to educate themselves about us. It's not going to happen. If we want people to be educated, we need to educate them. this is one of the ways we do that.

However, I understand the panic people have because some people even in America do not have insurance.

snippet.textDisplay: As a Mexican American who has family members that have immigrated from Mexico, I don’t mind that a white woman wrote a fictional story about Mexicans crossing the border. I’m all about awareness if it was provided with the best of intentions, flash back to the Kelly Osborne comment about Mexicans and cleaning toilets 🤦🏽‍♀️ What does bug me is the fact that she is now saying she is Latinx when she clearly stated she’s white before the book release. Also mentioning that her husband is an immigrant...from Ireland. 😑 I have a problem with people lying in order to gain success & that is the bigger issue.  I’m unsure if I’ll be purchasing the book because I personally have relatives that can tell me their stories & I’m not comfortable supporting someone skewing about their identity, but if the book can provide awareness to those who often ignore or don’t support the issue with Mexican immigrants then I am all for it. Best to her & her support for my community, even if it came with a few hiccups.

snippet.textDisplay:
The American Dirt Story is bullshit. First off, let’s go back in time to Uncle Tom’s Cabin. A story, written by a white woman, that is widely considered one of the most influential pieces of literature in the reformation of race relations in the US. Believe it or not, white people can have opinions and are allowed to recognize inequalities in the world.
Furthermore, why is race a huge deal now? Why is it a defining characteristic? I thought we were all supposed to be one people, one in the same. The fight used to be for us to all be considered the same, and now the world become all about race differences
